HIST 321 China from Present to Past provided a wide range of learning spanning geographic regions and historical time periods. The readings of the course are drawn from a variety of historical contexts ranging from autobiographical content of the Song Dynasty and Qing Dynasty eras to modern scholarship on Chinese history and development to current events topics pertaining to the U.S.-China relationship, among others. Professor Hansens lectures were made especially engaging by her perceptive treatment of the subjects at hand, enabled by the expertise she has acquired throughout her career of studies of Chinese history and travels to the country. 

The format of the course entailed class lectures, a midterm examination, an oral presentation, a paper, a timed policy memo assessment, weekly sections, and a variety of optional course activities that took place outside of the classroom. These many opportunities for exposure to primary and secondary source materials and scholarship on Chinese history made the course especially enriching. The design of the course also prompted students to engage with Chinese history in meaningful and collaborative ways, not only during course discussions and presentations but also outside of the classroom in conversations with classmates and instructors.

The organizational structure of the course gives students an immersion into Chinese history and its present-day significance that is grounded in genuine scholarship and is contextualized within the modern arena of historical and political debates surrounding Chinas past. The intellectual forthrightness of the course is one of its foremost strengths. Great emphasis is placed throughout the course on drawing information from sources of various regions of the political spectrum and on analyzing the motives and biases that influence much of the information available to modern audiences regarding China, its history, and its people. 

Professor Hansens excellent teaching and the numerous strengths of the course were supplemented by the contributions of the two talented teaching fellows of the course, George Remisovsky and Arina Mikhalevskaya. George and Arina directed section discussions very well and furnished many thoughtful insights during these weekly section gatherings. George gave a phenomenal in-class lecture that remains particularly memorable for its spirited delivery and depth of reasoning.

Strengths - This class felt very foundational for establishing my understanding of Chinsse history. I feel a lot more confident about taking more Chinese history courses in the future. 

Weaknesses - I don't think I liked the way the class was structured for a few reasons, but also I don't quite know how to restructure it. First, I don't like the disjointed timeline of the class. There's a large portion of history between the Song Dynasty and Qing Dynasty that we ignored in the class. We also didn't cover the transition from the Qing Dynasty to Communist-era China. I think jumping between discrete points of time and attempting to draw connections between such disparate periods of time made me feel like we missed a lot of important linkages in the middle. Second, some part of me wishes we learned each time period separately, as in we discussed the Song Dynasty first, as in family life, economics, and political protest all at once. I know that the class wants us to draw linkages between time periods, which is why we learned about all three time periods in terms of family life, and then revisited all three time periods for economics, then political protest. However, sometimes I felt that we were forced to draw linkages that didn't feel very intuitive (especially in the first paper). I don't know if revising the structure of the course would make the linkages more apparent, but I think the problem with separated units of family life, economics, and political protests is that we cannot fully examine how, for example, economics affects family life and political protests.

I think I would recommend this course for anyone who is interested in studying Chinese history. Chinese history is such a large topic that we still only skim the surface with this class, but the advantage of taking this class is that we are introduced to a lot of terminology and context that can help in further study of Chinese history. 

However, I wonder if a class that didn't try to force linkages between past and present but instead just taught the class as "here's a primer on some periods in Chinese history" might be more helpful. Some lectures (especially those from the Song Dynasty) ended up feeling a bit irrelevant, but only because the class was sold as "here's how the past relates to the present", even though learning the history of the Song Dynasty is probably more helpful in learning the history of the subsequent dynasties like Yuan and Ming compared to much later time periods like modern China.
